segments.text: Today is March the 5th, 1990.
This will be an interview with Dr. Lawrence Wolkin, professor at Texas A&M University, an interview recorded in his home.
Dr. Wolkin, I understand that the first week in June of 1989, you had the opportunity to be in China.
And those of us in the United States were watching what was developing in Tiananmen Square.
Could you share with us what you were doing in China at that time?
I had gone over there.
I got there on Monday, the 29th of May, and was going to be there for two weeks to participate in some conferences that were going on in Beijing.
Actually, the conference for the second week

had already been canceled because of these student demonstrations, but they were going to go ahead with the conference during the first week, which was focusing on Americans doing business in China and some of the problems I might run into, designed mainly for businessmen who wanted to meet their counterparts in China so they could start doing some negotiations for some joint ventures or buying and selling the products.
Because I had to get my ticket early, I couldn't change the time on it, so I was going to be there for two weeks anyway.

So I figured that second week, instead of going to the conference, I would spend some time visiting with my friends and trying to, as best I could, determine how much change had taken place in China since we were there in 85, 86.

And during that second week, my two older children were going to come over and practice their Chinese and visit with some of their friends and see some of the places that they come out when we were there in Beijing.
How long before this particular event did you make your plans?
Did you know?
It was early in the spring in March when I had gotten permission from the university
to go over there and have gotten some funding from a couple of the centers there at the university to attend these meetings and conduct some more research there in China.
But as the demonstrations were going on, of course, I was keeping as close in contact with the people that I knew in China and with people that I knew here
having them help me interpret the events that were going on as they were watching them on television as to whether or not it would be safe to go over there.
So it was over a month and a half time period there.
We were watching the news very closely and trying to determine what the situation really was in China and if it really posed any threat to foreigners.
Okay.
Well, it sounds like you were in a position to have some inside knowledge with these other people.
You've mentioned being there in the school year of 1985, 86?
Yes.
In what situation, what basis were you there?
I was there to teach at a university there in Beijing, the University of International Business and Economics.
each year bring in several foreign experts from different parts of the world.

Some of them there are there to help with English language for the students at the university, but I was there to teach Western economics, international trade, international finance, because the students at this university would be assigned after graduation to
major corporations in China that are involved in international trade.
They'd be assigned into the Ministry of Finance, into the Bank of China, into the various levels of the Chinese economy and government that are dealing with foreign countries.
And as part of the reforms at that time, China was looking towards opening the country economically in other ways to the rest of the world.
And they needed some people who were trained in
the ways of doing business in these other countries, because the Chinese do things in a very different way, and they need to have some understanding of how business is conducted in other countries.
And the school that these students were attending, what was that called?
It's the University of International Business and Economics.
It's one of their best universities.
The universities in China are much more specific than our universities here.
in that they focus on a single subject area.
The one that I was at focused on international business and economics.
There was another university in Beijing that focused on Chinese business and economics.
Even within the different sciences, there are different universities that are devoted to biological sciences versus physics, chemistry.
Their universities really are more comparable to a college
within a university here in the United States.
But under the reforms, they've been trying to somewhat broaden the scope of the courses that are taught in their various universities and institutions of higher education.
But they're in the process of rebuilding their whole educational system, which was disrupted, to put it mildly, during the Cultural Revolution.
Back in the 1960s.
from 1966 to 1976.
The university that I taught at was closed down for three years in the early 70s, as were most of the universities in China.
So they're just now trying to get their educational system back on track.
They lost a whole generation of educated people.
At the university level, you have professors who are in the 50-plus age range, and then
There's a big gap.
And then there's younger professors who are in their maybe 20s or early 30s who have gotten a college education in the last 10 years.
And there's a big gap in between them.
They just don't receive a college education.
They don't have the trained people who can teach the college classes.
So they're rebuilding.
Sounds as if that would be across all disciplines.
Yes, that everything was closed down.
Let me ask to clarify, you were teaching at Texas A&M, and then how did you get the position in China?
Did you go there singly?
Yeah, I just saw a little ad that said that there was a university in China that was looking for someone to teach economics during the coming academic year.
And if you wanted more information, here is an address.
to write off to, and it was in this strange sounding city called Beijing.
That was before we in America realized that Peking was really an outdated pronunciation, and Beijing is closer to the true Chinese.
I spent an hour in the map of the library trying to find out where the city was, but it was a small town out somewhere, and finally somebody came in and said that they thought that
that the Chinese had changed the name from Peking to Beijing.
Finally, we did find that on one map.
Come to realize you're talking about the capital of the country.
The capital of the country, yes.
Okay, so you answered an ad and then left the United States and spent a full nine months there.
We were there from the end of August in 85 to the first of July in 86.
Okay, now you said we.
Who was involved in that?
My entire family went with me.
My wife,
and our three children.
At the time, our daughter was in the eighth grade, and our oldest son was in the sixth grade, and our youngest son was two and a half years old.
So all five of you made the trip and lived there together.
All five of us lived that year in Beijing, yeah.
That must have been an experience.
So the friends you mentioned in 1989 being in contact with before you made the trip in Beijing,

late may of 1989 were these people that you had contacted or that you knew from your previous visit these were people that i had known from our previous visit and had come into contact with since then in communications back and forth division just a kind of off the wall question in terms of how does the language how did how did you deal with that both the first visit and then the second

I do not speak Chinese, and that was one of the things that I wrote the university when I first responded to that ad, but the university I taught at, the students had six years of English before they got there, because English is the language that she used in her national business.
The Chinese even use English as their language in business deals with the Soviet Union and the other Eastern Bloc nations.
The students at the university where I taught
their freshman and sophomore year took more intensive study in English.
And as a matter of fact, my wife ended up teaching a freshman English class.
And they had some other foreign experts there who taught different courses in English.
So the seniors and graduate students that I was working with understood English quite well and could make themselves understood.
language was not a problem.
Our two older children learned quite a bit of Chinese while we were there.
My wife and I ended up spending most of our time helping some Chinese work on improving their English, so we did not take full advantage of the opportunity we had of learning some Chinese.
Again, when I went back in 89, we had some interpreters
at the conferences we were at.
And some of the Chinese who were making presentations spoke English.
It's, I guess, typical around the world.
We as Americans go everywhere and expect everybody else to speak English.
And I really feel ashamed of myself and our country in the sense that we have very few people who are bilingual.
We always depend on the other people to speak our language.
And I think that we need to improve on that.
You found that the same when you traveled to Japan and so forth.
In Japan and in Europe, it's not unusual to run across people who speak two, three, four languages fluently.
Okay.
I'd like us to kind of go back then.
You flew from the United States into the airport in Beijing.
Yes.
We stopped in Shanghai on the way, but that's where we entered the country for customs purposes and then on up to Beijing.
Okay.
I understand that the airport is about 30 kilometers from the center of the city, or what kind of a ride did you have in?
I'm kind of curious, when you got there and landed, what you were seeing or keeping an eye out for as you headed towards where the conference would be held.
The airport in Beijing is, in several situations, intercontinental airport there in Houston, and it's outside of town about
15, 20 miles on the northeast side of town.
Once I landed, a friend of mine came and picked me up and took me to the hotel where I was staying on the northeast side of Beijing.
So I was able to, on that ride in, both get some information about what was going on in China and in Beijing in particular, and able to see for myself
what was happening.

Of course, one of the things I was looking for was any evidence of troop build-ups around Beijing, because in the weeks prior to that, there had been some troop movement into Beijing, and a number of times the troops had tried to go into the capital, but had been stopped by people coming up the streets.
So these are some of the things that I was looking for, and trying to, just a general impression of
what things had changed since we had been there three years before.
I think you have a unique opportunity to make that contrast, having been there earlier and then coming back this other time.
The friend that you were with, what perspective was he coming from?
Another professor or student?
This was a Chinese friend, and he was trying to explain the situation to me there.
and felt quite comfortable that things were peaceful and would remain so.
He was amazed at the response among the Chinese people in general to the student demonstrations in that in the past, and I know we were there in 85-86, people were very hesitant to
to voice their opinions, to let anybody else know how they really felt about something.
Because there have been periods in the past, back in 1958, for example, Mao Zedong decided that it would be all right for people to criticize the government in a constructive way.
And this was going to be a change in government policy, to allow people to make comments that would be used then to help improve the situation.
After about a month and a half of that, decided that this was not a good idea.
And retroactively, the people who had voiced their opinions had been severely punished.
So this had happened a number of times.
And the Chinese people were well aware of that.
So they were very hesitant about voicing opinion on anything political.
I even ran into that problem in my classes when I was teaching in 85-86.

Even though it was politically acceptable to talk about opening China to the West and doing business with the West, the students were hesitant to act too interested in the things that I was talking about, because everyone in China has a file.
And that file follows you your whole life.
And if something that could in a later time be construed to be

something negative, something potentially bad, then because the government owns all the factories, they own all the businesses, they assign you where to live, they assign you where to work and that, that you can be punished just through your work assignments and that.
So students were hesitant to ask questions
and seemed too interested in what we were talking about because someone else might inform on them.
And if the government policy were to change, that could be held against them.
You were very aware of this policy of the file following the student from the earlier time.
Knowing that and then hearing about the demonstrations for democracy, how did
How did you feel about that in terms of, well, how do you think the students dealt with that, knowing the file was following them?
Well, I think the students who were in Tiananmen Square and initiated the demonstrations, they were well aware of the severe punishments that they could expect to receive from the government.
And I think

that most of the students felt that perhaps that would be the only thing that would be done to them, that the government might send in some troops or some secret police and beat them up and arrest them.
But no one really believed that the government would use the brutal force that they did in putting down the demonstration.
This had happened a number of times in the past.
I remember when I was watching, before I went over there, I was watching the news coverage of what was going on in Tiananmen Square.
The news reporters did not really have a very good understanding or a feel for what was going on in China.
They knew that something different was happening.
They knew that something rather dramatic was happening.
But, for example, every morning the news commentators would
make the comment that the students seemed to be very relieved that they'd made it through another night and seemed to be much more relaxed, that during the night they were much more nervous.
But the news commentators didn't know why.
Well, back in 1976, a similar but a much smaller scale demonstration had taken place when Zhou Enlai had died.
And some students had gathered in Tiananmen Square
to mourn his death.
And after several days, the government decided that they did not want the demonstrations going on.
So in the middle of the night, about 1 o'clock in the morning, they sent some secret security police into Tiananmen Square.
And they arrested, beat severely, and even shot some of the demonstrators who were there.
But cleaned up the square real nice so that by the next morning when everybody went to work,
it looked like nothing had happened.
And it took four or five years for the word of that to spread throughout China because the government owns all the news media sources of information.
People find out about things by word of mouth.
So the students who were at Tiananmen Square were well aware of what had happened in the past, and that's why they were very concerned about the nighttime.
They figured if the government was going to make their move,
that they were going to do that at night, but the news commentators did not understand that.

It must have been a little frustrating to watch American newscasters make their comments about something, and like you say, they're not understanding the background behind it, coming from a lack of information or knowledge from being inside China.
Can we kind of go back to Tiananmen Square in terms of when you came into Beijing in 1989, what was your first view or the first time you saw these students in Tiananmen Square?
The first chance I got was on Wednesday of that week.
The students had put up the Goddess of Democracy statute for Tuesday.
tour group was going, or the conference was going to a meeting near the square, and so we drove by the square.
So I had a chance to view it on the bus from Chang'an Avenue, which is that main street that runs east to west in Beijing.
And then later that afternoon, after our meetings were finished, I went down to Tiananmen Square, walked around in the square for an hour, and took quite a few pictures and
was just overwhelmed by the people who were involved in the demonstration in that it was a much broader demonstration than just the students.
The students were the Catholics.
And again, our news media focused on the students.
But the vast majority of the people who, and when I say
the vast majority, we're talking about on a couple of occasions, there were millions of people who were out in the streets demonstrating to support the students.
Of all age groups, I'm saying.
These were people of all age groups.
These were people from all levels of society within Beijing, from workers in the factories
to people in the ministries.
May I ask how you would make that determination that these were workers or that these were people of different economic levels?
In some cases by the banners and that that they had and you can also tell by the way that a lot of the people dressed and the age of course that's
you could see people who were very, very young and also people who were very old in their fifties and sixties.
So you had a broad spectrum of society.
Then on this Wednesday afternoon that you're talking about, you were on foot walking through the square?
Yes, I went on foot down there and was walking through the square and taking

Pictures, not only of the statue, but of the students' living conditions there, the tents, the banners and that, the signs that they had up, so that when I could get back, I could have some of my friends translate for me what these were.
One of them was a picture of Joy Lai, who many of the Chinese feel
helped moderate the excesses of Mao during the Cultural Revolution.
If it wasn't for him, things would have been much worse.
He was a person that many Chinese feel really had the good of the Chinese people in general at heart.
And part of the irony of this whole situation is that Li Peng, one of the hardliners and I think one of the major decision makers

sending the troops into Tiananmen Square was an adopted son of Zhou Enlai and I had interpreted when I got back one of the this sign had Zhou Enlai's picture and was saying as if Zhou Enlai was speaking to Li Peng saying that he was very disappointed the way Li Peng had turned out and the things that he had been doing

And one of the other sides was a little bit more pointed in its criticism of Li Peng, that had a caricature of Li Peng, but underneath it said that the PLA, the People's Liberation Army, ought to use Li Peng for their target practice.
You had students here at A&M who were able to translate those for you?
Yes, there are students here at A&M and a number of the other universities here in Texas that are from China.
As a matter of fact, I think in the U.S. now there's about 40,000 students from mainland China, so there are quite a few.
I think that was neat that you had your camera there to take some pictures.
You've shared one particular picture with me that we're looking at right now of the goddess of democracy.
Can you tell me what got you to take this particular picture?
Well, there were...
One thing that I saw that was very different from when we were there before was the fact that a lot of the Chinese, particularly the younger generation, now had cameras, Japanese modern cameras.
When we were there, the few people who had cameras were the old box-type cameras that you looked in from the top.
Yes.
And as a part of this new spirit of openness, there were,
quite a few people who, I said, were having their friends take pictures of themselves with the guys from Democracy in the background.
And there was one young lady in particular who had gotten all dressed up.
And they had some barrels that are out there in the square that were spread around.
And she got up on one of those.
So she was a little bit above the rest of the crowd.
and was flashing the V symbol for victory or peace in front of the Goddess of Democracy.
To me, it just kind of captured the whole emotion of the movement.
Of course, the students who have those pictures of themselves taken
in front of the Gaza Democracy, they have to guard those very carefully because the government is trying to get a hold of those to identify people who participated in the demonstration.
They're even using the footage that was shown on American TV to try to identify people.
So I'm sure that a lot of the people had their pictures taken.
They're very proud of those pictures, and hopefully they

They've hidden away somewhere where no one would be able to find them, but be able to pull them out at a later date to show that they participated in the demonstrations and that they were down in the square.
In effect, they're proof that they were there, but also a testimony could be used against them by the government, you're saying.
Can you share with us any, this young lady has on a very colorful outfit.
I think in one of the articles you wrote, you commented about how clothing has changed a great deal.
Was that typical of these students?
This was one of the things that I noticed.
When we were there, the young people and the university students in particular, they were rather fashion conscious and wanted more western dress and more colorful things.
had a very limited budget and there wasn't a whole lot of foreign clothing or even Chinese made but styled more towards west was available in 85-86.
But in returning this time, when we're back there in 85-86, still a large number of people were wearing the blue and green Mao coats with slacks to match and a blue or green Mao hat.
When I went back in 89, there were much fewer people.
But the only people that were still wearing that clothes were some of the older people.

Younger people, students, but also, again, workers, and even people in their mid-30s and 40s were wearing, if not outright colorful things, at least they were wearing white shirts, slacks, more Western type of clothing.
So this was one of the major changes that I saw since we'd been there.
This particular girl almost has on a sleeveless dress.
Could you share just a little bit about what the weather was like?
Well, in the summertime, Beijing is very hot.
It's much like Houston.
It's very hot and very humid.
So in the summertime, the Chinese typically wear things that are very lightweight because in the buildings, there is no air conditioning.
so you have to dress light.
Conversely, in the wintertime, people literally wear eight, ten layers of clothes because there's little or no heat in the buildings, and the way you keep warm is through your layers of clothes.
So, as I said, in the summer, it was warm.
It was in the mid-'80s, maybe lower-'90s.
Beijing, as is true of a lot of developing nations,
They do not have the sophistication of ideas about pollution control and things like that.
Most of their electricity that comes from burning coal.
So they're burning coal all year round.
So you have a fine coal dust that's in the air all the time.
It kind of makes the sky a gray.
You very seldom see a clear blue sky.
Even though there was more automobile and bus traffic this time than there was in 85, 86, there's still not anywhere near the automobile traffic that there is in Western nations.
In China mainly because people cannot own a car themselves.
Some of the factories and that, they're the ones that have the cars, and most of the people still get around on bicycles.
And Beijing is...
almost surrounded by mountains, so you have all this stuff gets trapped in there, so the sky quite often is just kind of a chalky gray color.
These students were out in this square, some of them at least, for six or seven weeks previous to the final week here.
What else did you observe as you were walking through the...
